Is there any particular reason for reordering the initialiser list?
diff_hunk:
@@ -1153,9 +1154,9 @@ CChainState::CChainState(
     BlockManager& blockman,
     ChainstateManager& chainman,
     std::optional<uint256> from_snapshot_blockhash)
-    : m_mempool(mempool),
-      m_blockman(blockman),
+    : m_blockman(blockman),

body:
988cfd8914f12ce87fb6ac6499326e140e840c1d

Instead of making this public, I think you should add a getter like `CoinsTip()` and an initialized like `InitCoinsDB`. Then you can revert what @stratospher asks in https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/23465/commits/988cfd8914f12ce87fb6ac6499326e140e840c1d#r756677595.

<!--cf906140f33d8803c4a75a2196329ecb-->
ð This pull request conflicts with the target branch and [needs rebase](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#rebasing-changes).

<sub>Want to unsubscribe from rebase notifications on this pull request? Just convert this pull request to a "draft".</sub>

Member variables must be initialized in the order in which they are declared. Otherwise, CI will throw `[-Werror = reorder]`.
See https://stackoverflow.com/questions/12222417/why-should-i-initialize-member-variables-in-the-order-theyre-declared-in
diff_hunk:
@@ -1153,9 +1154,9 @@ CChainState::CChainState(
     BlockManager& blockman,
     ChainstateManager& chainman,
     std::optional<uint256> from_snapshot_blockhash)
-    : m_mempool(mempool),
-      m_blockman(blockman),
+    : m_blockman(blockman),

body:
I changed the approach. Now, the `m_mempool` remains private and the getter and setter were added, as suggested by @stratospher in https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/23448#pullrequestreview-816441509 and @promag in https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/23465#discussion_r756697995 .

Not sure if this is idiomatic (c++ style). Otherwise, I can revert to original approach (with public `m_mempool`).
Done in https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/23465/commits/358f94a28176f766634d9701f1688abfcf761c28 .
maybe remove the sentence that starts with "usually"? https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/23437#discussion_r760377136
diff_hunk:
@@ -211,7 +211,6 @@ struct PackageMempoolAcceptResult
  * Try to add a transaction to the mempool. This is an internal function and is exposed only for testing.
  * Client code should use ChainstateManager::ProcessTransaction()
  *
- * @param[in]  pool               Reference to the node's mempool.
  * @param[in]  active_chainstate  Reference to the active chainstate.
  * @param[in]  tx                 The transaction to submit for mempool acceptance.
  * @param[in]  accept_time        The timestamp for adding the transaction to the mempool. Usually

body: Not a fan of adding test-only helpers to the real code. Might be better to move this to the test code.
Done in 3f7d1c1
diff_hunk:
@@ -211,7 +211,6 @@ struct PackageMempoolAcceptResult
  * Try to add a transaction to the mempool. This is an internal function and is exposed only for testing.
  * Client code should use ChainstateManager::ProcessTransaction()
  *
- * @param[in]  pool               Reference to the node's mempool.
  * @param[in]  active_chainstate  Reference to the active chainstate.
  * @param[in]  tx                 The transaction to submit for mempool acceptance.
  * @param[in]  accept_time        The timestamp for adding the transaction to the mempool. Usually

body: Good catch. Done in 3f7d1c1
there is already a `chainstate` symbol, so please use that. Also below it would be good to pass the same symbol to atmp, not the dummy one time and the "real" another time.
Done in 83b3697 . The same symbol is being passed to ATMP.
Thanks!
diff_hunk:
@@ -1153,9 +1154,9 @@ CChainState::CChainState(
     BlockManager& blockman,
     ChainstateManager& chainman,
     std::optional<uint256> from_snapshot_blockhash)
-    : m_mempool(mempool),
-      m_blockman(blockman),
+    : m_blockman(blockman),

body: This is wrong. It's returning a pointer, not a reference (and can't return a reference, since `m_mempool` may be null).
This is a behaviour chage. With this change, ATMP() is always called, even if `fAddToMempol` is false or the transaction is a coinbase.
Why does this return a pointer to the `CTxMemPool`, which never gets used. Can it just return void?

Does this still work if this line is moved up to l145 (i.e. immediately after the mempool is constructed). I think the test is easier to understand if the mempool pointer is set at the beginning and not updated.
I don't understand why you keep changing the formatting on this line, where all you need to do is remove the `m_mempool` argument. 160 columns is too wide for many people to do a side-by-side diff.
Done in 2cc5a38
utACK f1f10c0514fe81318c8b064f9dad0e2f9a2cd037
Post-merge ACK, modulo that I'm not sure if the CChainState::GetMempool() getter adds value. I've proposed a follow-up to remove it that picks up some of Marco's review feedback.
